The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: “TRAFFIO" AND THE STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: We feel that we owe no apology to our readers for devoting farther space to the subject of our railways and to the reforms therein which ore being, and will be, undertaken in the near future. Whilst we feel indebted to oar esteemed contributor *Traffic” for the articles with which ha has favored as, ha mast allow as to state that in oar opinion they fail to affect the conclusions we arrived at, and which we published on the first appearance of the Report of Lord Farrer's Commission. For convenience of publication, '-Traffic's" recent reply to oar remarks was divided into two parts, and for reason! which we will explain, our present remark) will to a great extent follow that division. If we take the first part of “Traffic's" contribution by itself; it shows signs of common ground on which this interesting subject can be usefully discussed. In our earliest remarks upon the Report of Lord Farrar's Commission we used the word "hur- riedly” in reference to the work performed, and we "ha to never been amongst those who considered that we had enough of the Com- mission's time. The circumstances of the case may certainly . have required that something more clearly defined and comprehensive was necessary, bat the authorities could hardly have expected this when selecting gentlemen os members of the Commission from among there who were so concerned in other important duties, that their absence from England could not be of long duration. We regarded the matter ourselves much in the light of a reference to a consulting phy- sician who gives his opinion and leaves the are to others. In the likening of a railway to any other commercial undertaking we are greatly in accord with "Traffic." We agree
Sunlight A great economiser and saver of time, health, and strength. Laundry worries went out of woman's life when Sunlight Soap came into it It is the purest Soap going. Soap

that there is nothing in it which any man of sufficient practical knowledge and experience cannot master, and, if necessary, reform when accepted lines have been agreed upon. When, however, we come to "Traffic’s” arrangements of deportments, and the position he would accord to the traffic manager, we are com- pelled to part company. If we re tarn to his principles of trade and commerce, we do not find that, in practice, the head of the sales department has absolute control over baying and building operations. The opinion of the soles manager tho old be valuable, and taken accordingly, bat the bayer and architect look to someone higher thin him m their master. It is true that the success of a railway may depend more upon the traffic manager than upon any other official, and in matters of complication or competition the railway's earnings, and the welfare of the country, may greatly depend upon his wisdom and ex- perience. In the matter of expenditure of every kind, is representations of the requirements of his departments must carry snob weight (involving os they do the security of life and property), that they cannot be lightly set aside. Upon him depends to a great extent whether money is wisely spent, withheld, or wasted, although it is invariably held that he is not concerned in its expenditure, except in so far os it may apply 'to his own establish- ment, for his training os a rale would not fit him to deal with it, any more than the train- ing of the responsible heads of other depart- ments would fit them to carry oat their work as contractors under his guidance. This brings as to the second part of “Traffic’s’* reply. We feel that it suddenly descends to a kind of criticism of little value To the supervision of the general manager over the whole of the executive staff might be added "and of all its works,” without convey- ing the strained meaning attached to it. There is necesarilly a chain of responsibility, not only on a railway, bat in every department of it, and the Commission’s competition treated as absurd in the case of the general manager would, as interpreted by "Traffic,” be also absurd in the case of any important depart- ment of any large railway. Whether Kantara is interlocked or not, whether appearances, as hurriedly seen,were for oraganic it,or whether a mistake has been mode in the name or in anything else ; whether signallers may or may not have their books to passing trains ; or whether existing and local circumstances jus- tify certain of the Commission's remarks, are matters too technical for is to touch upon. We took the Report as adopted generally by the authorities, including the head of the railway, and hod every right to export that Mr. Bury’s wide experience and high position at home made him a reliable adviser to the Commission in his part of the work. If we bold to this opinion and are under a mistake, wo are at any rate in the good company, not only of the proprietors of the Great Northern Railway but of numbers who seek and accept Mr. Bary’s services.

div.head: LORD KITCHENER’S OFFICIAL RESIDENCE.
div.p: Since he has been in Simla this year Lord Kitchener has been much occupied in superin- tending the improvements which were com- menced last year in the lower bungalow which forms the main portion of Snowdon, hie Excellency's official residence. Snowdon was originally bought from General Pater Innes by Lord Roberta in 1873-1, and was purchased from the latter, say* "Men and Women o India,” by the Government for about Rs.80,000. Since Lord Kitchener has been in residence there he has made so many alterations that the house can honestly be said to hare been com- pletely transformed. Not only has he built a delightful dining-room, possessing oar red wall and ceilings, bat he has constructed a main hall and staircase, which are ornamented with trophies of the chase and spoils of war, Among those latter may be mentioned the curious coat-of-arms in carved oak which originally formed the back of tin canopy under which President Kroger used to sit is the Raad Seal at Pretoria, and beneath which the famous ultimatum, which led to the rub of his country and himself; was signed. Then there are ban- ners and Hags taken at Omdnrman as well as in South Africa, and curious old arms without number. The old ball-room has been consider- ably enlarged and improved, the electric light U being installed throughout the entire block of buildings, and the construction of a library promise to convert "Snowdon" into a residence which will ha worthy of the famous soldier who ` has taken an interest in its improvement.

div.head: REVIEWED BY THE KING WILD ENTHUSIASM
div.p: PORTSMOUTH, August 9. The King has received the French fleey. The weather was showery. his Majesty, the Prince of Wales, and the Duke of Connaught afterwards lunched with Admiral Caillard on board the French flagship.
The French fleet has entered the harbour. This is an unprecedented honor to a foriegn fleet. It anchored amid the wildest enthusiasm. (Reuter).
COWES, August 9. After the naval review, the King lunched on board the Massena. He exchanged toasts with tht eAdmiral celebrating the union of the two countries.
The French fleet is on its way to Ports- mouth. (Havas).

div.head: THE PEACE CONFERENCE MEETING OF ENVOYS
div.p: PORTSMOUTH (N.H.) August 9. The envoys are stopping at the same hotel. They proceeded to the Navy Yard ub separate launched, this time precedence being given to the Russians. Each were saluted the 19 guns. Rear-Admiral Mead recieved them and con- ducted them to the stores building, where they inspected the arrangements for the Conference and lunched, afterwards returning to the hotel.

M. Witte, in an interview said that he would leave nothing unattempted to conclude peace, but all depended upon the Japanese demands, and in case of failure the world would judge who was responsible. (Reuter.)

PORTSMOUTH (N.H.) August 9. The Peace Envoys met in the most cordial manner. Their credentials were found satisfac- tory. The English and French languages will be jointly used and the minutes recorded in both languages.
The real business will begin to-morrow. (R.)
NEW YORK August 9. It is understood that he programme of the Peace COnference for to-day was confined to the examination of credentials and the dis- cussion of the language to be employed. (R.)
PORTSMOUTH (N.H.) August 10. The plenipotentiaries will sit three hours each morning and two hours and half in the afternoon. (Reuter.)

div.head: CRETAN INSURRECTION. BOMBARDMENT BY RUSSIANS
div.p: CANEA, August 9. The Cretan rebels having seized and refused to give up the Custon House at Castellu a Russian gunboat bombarded the village till it was destroyed. Two Russians were wounded. (REuter)

div.head: HOME CRICKET
div.p: LONDON, August 9. Yorkshire beat Lsucashire by 44 runs. Glou- cestershire beat Sussex by 5 wickets. The other matches have been abandoned.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: H.H.S AIDA arrived at Alexandria from Port Said at noon to-day.
FATAL SCORPION.- A native of Old Cario died yesterday from the effects of the string of a scorpion.
STREET ACCIDENT.- A Syrian boy, 9 years of age, was run down and injured by a carriage in the Rue St, Athanase on Monday evening.
OFFICRS FROM THE YEMEN.- Fifteen Turkish officers, returning from the Yemen, arrived at Alexandria yesterdat and left in the after- noon for Constantinople.
NEW HARBOUR PASS.- The British Admiralty dredger St. Giles arrived at Alexandria from Malta this mornign in connection with the dredging of the new harbour pass.
FOOLISH LENIENCY.- A certain Said Ali Rifaa who recently beat his wife to death has been condemmed by the Tanta Native Tribunal to 5 years hard labour.
ITALIAN DROWNED. An Italian named Vincenzo was drowned yesterday near Bringi Ramleh. His body was recovered by the police and sent to the hospital for the holding of an autopsy.

STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Waili district of Cario during the night of the 11th isnt. and at dawn of the 12th inst. will be poisoned by the police. Dogs found at the quays, ALexandria on the same night will also be poisoned.

SUEZ CANAL.- 15 vessels passed through the Canal on th e7th inst. of which 8 were British, 3 German, 2 French, 1 Austrian, 1 Portuguese. The receipts for the day were frs. 427,445.03 making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 1,562,345.18

CLAIM JUMPERS BEWARE- Sheikh Ali Said Farag a sheikh el belad in the MAriout dis- trict who is well known for his campaign against annexationists of GOvernment land in the MAriout districtm and their buildings, has been appointed omdeh of MAriout by the Ministry of the Interior.

THE PLAUGE.- Yesterday's plague bulletin reports three deaths at ALexandria, One of these was a Copt woman of the Minet el Bassal district, the second was a Copt beggar girl of the Khafr el Ghates district and the third a native hawker also a woman who was found dead at Faradeh.

SANITARY DEPARTMENT.- The contract for the construction of the Anti-Rabic Institute, and for thr enlargement of the Hygienic Ins- titete at CArio has been given to M.G. Fucili. Messrs Grant Bondi and Chinn have obtained the contract for the drainage and sa- nitary installations.

A NATIVE QUARREL.- Two natives quarrel- led with each other yesterday at the Customs and fought with such vigour that they both received injuries sufficiently severe to neces- sitate prolonged medical treatment.The more severely injured of the two is likely to be under treatment for twelve days.

ST. MARK'S CHURCH.- on Sunday next (the eighth Sunday after Trinity) the Chruch of St. MArk's will be reopened for divine service. The services will be as follows;- celebration of Holy COmmunion, 8 a.m. matin and short address, 11 a.m. evensong and short address, 1.15 p.m.

CARIO POLICE SCHOOL.- Yesterday morning the Police School was transferred from Boulac to the Citadel where it will remain until the completion of the new school which is to be built at Abbassieh. It is anticipated that this school, which will cost about 60,000 will be ready for occupation about the beginning of 1908.

COPTIC PERVERTS.-Yesterday morning two Coptic women named Nimet and Fatma appeared at the Governorat to announce their intention of becoming Moslems. After the ususal formalities and a refusal on the part of the women to listen to a priest's advice they were sent to the Mehkemeh Charieh where their conversion to Islam was duly re- corded and confirmed in the presence of the Cadi.

AFFRAY NEAR THE CUSTOM HOUSE.-Yester- day a Greek driving a baker's cart on which two of his friends sat, came into collision with an arabieh in the Sharia el Gedida near the Custom-house. The arbaghi immediatel cursed the father and the faith of the Greek who lescended from hid seat and offered battle. A number of Arabs who were pasing joined in the fray and not only mishandled the Greek driver but hauled his two harmless compan- ions from the cart, and might have done them some injury had not the policfe intervened, We regret to notice a certain tendency on th epart of a section of the Arab population of Alex- andria to joinn in any and every quarrel between Europeans and Arabs, quite regardless whether it concerns them or not.

div.head: THE COMMERCIAL TREATY
div.p: We are informed that the negotiations between the Egyptian and Hellenic Govern- ments as to the renewal of the commercial treaty between the two countries, which was recently denounced by the Egyptian Government, are at present suspended. This is not due to the issue of any sort of "ultimatum" by the Government - which has not dreamt of such a course- but owing tot he absence on leave of the Minister for Foreign Affairs Boutros PAsha Ghali and other important officials. The negotiations will be resumed in the early autumn.

div.head: ANIMALS FOR THE "ZOO"
div.p: Captian Flower director of the Zoological Gardens arrived at Cario early this morning on his return from an expedition to the Sudan where he has been enlarged in forming a large and varied collection of wild animals to add to the already large and magnificant callection in his charge. Three Afrian elephants one giraffe (eleven feet in height) fifteen lions two saddle- bill storks, antelopes, gazelles, oranes, parrots, turtles, crocodiles, and many more beasts too numerous to catalouge have accompanied Captian Flower from up the Nile. These addititons to the "Zoo" should attract more visitors than ever to what msut now be the best collection of the kind in theAfrica Contintent.

div.head: WELLS AND THEIR POLLUTION
div.p: We yesterday had occasion to refer to the use of polluted wells by the proprietors of bakeries and to express the hope that the authorites would see their way to check it, To-day we wish to draw their attention to the "holy" well in the mosque was built aro0und and above a well, the water of which was supposed to process healing properties and to bless women who drank of it with healthy off-spring The building is now, and has been for a long time, very largley frequented by women who are suffering from a variety of diseases and who have recourse to the water in the hope of their silments being cured. Not only is the water in the mosque used for bathing by these women, but those who are desirous of bearing children actually drink the foul liquid.

In presence of such a scandalous state of things we think there is room for action on the part of the authorities, Would it not be pos- sible for them to do something to check a practice which can only lead to the dissemination of disease, and constitutes a grave public danger?

div.head: TEH LATE SIGNOR TOMISANI
div.p: A Cario correspondent writes;- I have just heard of the death, at Milan, of Angelo tomi- sani, who, as many readers of the "Egyptian Gazette" will rememebr sang at the Verdi Theatre and at ALexandria. I had the pleasure of hearing him in several opera at the Verdi and I confess to having enjoyed his singing far more than that of many whose names are better known and reputations moe firmly established and more highly remunerated. I remmeberespecially two operas- nMignon and Rigoletto. Mignon both in Cario and in ALex- andria, was a deservedly brilliant success for M. Tomisani and in Rigoletto his version of "La donna e mobile" was all one could have asked for. I do not pretend to knoen anything about his former career or training but I do assert (and many people will bear me out) that he had a delightful voice of most charming tone and timbre especially in the higher notes of his register. THe delicacy of these was very much beyond what an average audience in this country expects. What he might have done no one can tell. what he has done, as I and others heard it was I will maintian of unusual promise and merit. I shall always be glad that I heard him sing, and more than sorry to know that an untimely death prevents us from hear- ing him again.

div.head: MEETING AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: A preliminary meeting was held at 5 p.m. yesterday ay H.B.M's Consulate with a view to hearing the explanations of the promoters of the British manufactureers exhibition and to the appointment of an advisory commitee The chair was kindly taken by Mr. Ambroise A. Ralli, who called on the promoters of the exhibition Messrs. LEgge and Prior to ex- plain the scope and outlines of their scheme to the meeting.

Mr. Prior then read a statement summaris- ing the scheme in which he pointed out that British trade in Egypt needed some stimulus which would be supplied by the holding of such an exhibition. He then gave the main outlines of the scheme. The organisers intended to give their whole time and attention to mak- ing the exhibition a success and proposed to act as managers supported by an advisory committee. The exhibition was to be confined to British and Colonial goods, and would be held between the months of December and February nxext thereby enabling exhibitors to show the same goods at Alexandria and Cario. The exhibiton would be open to all, classes of goods which would be arranged as far as possible in their respective sections and would be an onject lesson to the Egyptian public of the capabilities of British manufacturers.

It was expected that suitable and central sites would be obtainable in Cario and Alex- andria. Exhibitors would be charged according to the space allotted them , and a small en- trance dee would be paid by the public but as it was not desired to preclude admission to possible buyers a certain number of free tickets would be issued ot exhibitors for dis- tribution amongst locla merchants and others. Exhibitors would be charged the cost of erect- ing stalls according to their plans. A band would be present and other arrangements made to attract the public while everything would be done to advertise the exhibition bith in England and Egpyt. Local agents of hoem manyfactureers, whether British or foreign would be interviewed on order to obtain their support and circulars owuld be forwarded to the most importnat British manu- facturers and merchants explaining the aims of the exhibition and inquiring whether they were willing to support it. THe organisers above-mentioned would start a owrkinf ex- pense fund with sufficient capital to carry out the scheme. The majority of the local merchnay and agents had been interviews and had one and all promised to support the project while very favorable reports as to the attitude of home manufacturers had been received from Mr. Murray the London agent of the exhibition.

An advisory committes was then formed consisting of Messrs. Williams, Naggar, Morrid, E. Kirby A .J. Venieri (representing Messr. Thos. Cook and Son's engineering Dept.) and Mr. A. G- Pengue with power to add to their number. Several well-known memebers of British houses absent from the meeting had previously expressed their willingness to serve on the committee if called upon.
The meeting terminated at 6.15 p.m. after a vote of thanks to the chairman and to Mr. Freeman had been carried nem. con.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE
div.p: NEW STEAMER ORDERED

The Khedivil Mail Steamship and GRaving Dock Company have placed an order with Messrs. San, Hunter, Wigham, Richardson and Co., of Wallsend-on-Tyne, for the construction of a new first-class passenger steamer fitted with the latest improvements and comforts. We underestand that this latest addition to the company's fleet is intended to run on the GReece Turey line and will have a speed of 18 knots per hour, thus enabling passengers for the Pireaus to reach their destin- tion the day after leaving ALexandria only one one being spent at sea. The vessel, which will cost from 90,000 to 100,000 will be completed in about ten months.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT, LTD.
div.p: The Corporation's schemist reports from El Der, Kharga Oasis: Phosphates have been found to occur in three parallel beds close to El Der and extending north and soutth, The outcrop has been traced for more than a mile and a small sample brought form the road to Dabadib shows that it continues far to the north.

The vast extent of some of the aluminous deposits and the ease with which they are worked renders them a valuable source of aluminium sulphate the only plant required for the preparation being a series of leaching and evaporating tanks protected from sand storms and dust and some means of crushing the ore.

(The report of the consulting engineers, Mesrs Lake and Currie dealt with the known earthy minerals of the Oasis of Dakhla only. The chemist has been at work in Kharga during the past few months investigating the mineral possibilities of that district.)

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Messageries mail steamer Equateur, arrived at Marseilles yesterday from Alex- andria.
The S.S. Asiatic Prince from Middlesbrough and Antwerp left Malta on Tuesday and is due here on Saturday with PAssengers and general cargo, etc.

div.head: PROPOSED INCREASE OF CAPITAL
div.p: The following circular has been issued to the shareholders of the Nile Valley Com- pany:

The option which was given to Mr. J.B. Robinson to take up the 47,000 unissued shares in your company at 30s per share, has expired through effluxion of time. The direc- tors only having been authorised to dispose of these shares to Mr. Robinson at the price stated and note at a lower figure with out first consulting the shareholders and furtehr work- ing capital being required to successfully and quickly develop your property have deemed it advisable to give the shareholders an oppor- tunity now that the 47,000 shares are freem to suscribe for the same at par on the conditions stated below.

The additional capital is required for the following purposes: (1) The erection of Cornish pump, which is now on the ground (2) The erection of a permanent hoisting plant also now on the ground. (3) THe vigorous development of the mine at depth . (4) To considerably increase the crushing capacity of the battery. A large amount of gold as the ahreholders are aware, has been extracted in the pass from the phenomenally rich chute of ore, but it is not expected that the specimen gold still left between the 108 ft and 150 ft levels wil do much more than discharge the present liabilities of the company. No. 1 shaft is down to within a few feet of the 200 ft level and it is intended as son as the shaft reaches this level to drive about 50 it in order to pick up th erich chute. The drives north and south at the 200 ft level form No. 5 shaft are proving the reef to be wider, and of a far more per- manent appearence than in the upper leyals.

It is therefore proposed to offer the said 47,000 shares tot he shareholder at 1 per share payable as to 5s per share on application 5s per share on allotment and the balance of 10s per share within two months form the date of allotment. A special settlement will be applied for on the Stock Exchange on shres now subscribed for so that all shares may rank alike.

div.head: LAST OF THE BRITANNIA
div.p: A somewhat pathetic incident in the annals of H.M. Navy is about to take place in the closing of His Majesty's Ship Britannia at Dartmouth on of the old wooden walls of England and Specil nterest attatched to the distribution of prizes on the 2nd August as it was the last function on board the old cadet ship. The cadets after the holidays, will be housed in the new NAval College erected at Dartmouth at a cost of nearly 500,000. Admiral Sir Lewis Beaumont distibuted the prizes and said although the wooden walls were at last to be swept away, and a new system inaugurted the traditions of the grand old ship would remain Captian Wemyas com- manding the Dartmouth and Osborne Colleges declared that they all looked upon the occasion as not only an interesting but a pathetic one. Not a naval officer but ws sorry to see the altered conditions of naval wartare in recent years rendered it imperative. Cadets from the crusiers Isis and Highflyar wre present in full numbers, and they gave volley after volley of cheers for the Britannia and the new college.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS
div.p: By kind permission of Major H.O.D> Hick- man and officers 2nd ROyal Inniskilling Fusiliers and the band will preform the following programme of music in the Esbekieh Garden to-morrow (Friday) evening from 9 to 11 p.m.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H> the Khedive leaves Divonne for Paris to-morrow and will proceed to Constantinople in a few days' time. It is hoped that the Khedive will be present at the fetes held in the Capital on September 1, the acceasion-day of the Sultan.
Judge Tuck is expected to return from leave on the 14th inst. and will act as president of the Mixed Tribunals until the return of M. Pruniere.
Mr. W.H. and Miss Talbot thank all of their frieds who have expressed sympathy with them in their recentorial bereavement.
Ibrahim Bey Nabih, Mudir of Dakhalieh has been grauted leave for onr month, to date form the 16th inst.
M.M.A Rosenkart and Said T. Samaka have been authorised by the Sanitary Adminis- tration to practise as pharmacists in Egypt.

div.head: COLLISION IN HARBOUR
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)

Port Said, Wednesday The P.O. mail steamer Isis which arriv- ed from Brindisi at dawn with mails and passengers for the waiting S.S> Egypt, after having transferred her mails, as is usual by going alongside the larger ship was steaming down to her regular mornings, when for some unexplained reason a large steam-hopper crashed into her. The damage to the latter is serious and she was at once beached to avoid the possibility of sinking. The Isis is also much damaged but will be ready for her next voyage on Tueday.

div.head: THE AIDA
div.p: H.H.S. Aida arrived from the Canal and Red Sea ports this morning, and is to proceed to Alexandria some time to-night.

div.head: KILLED BY A TRAIN
div.p: (FROM UR CORRESPONDENT)

Minet el Gamh, Wednesday One night last week a native workman who was sleeping close to the railway line was caught by a passing goods train and dragged along by it for a distance of about 6 kilometers the accident not being discovered until the train drew up at the staion. Both the head and legs were severed from the body of the unfortunate man and the corpsepresented a most ghastly sight. It appears that a fig tree which belonged to the decseased was planted near the line and the man had lain down there with the object of keeping away thieves

div.head: DEATH FROM ALCOHOL
div.p: On Saturday last a man who had been drink- ing freely entered the Minet el CAsh train for Zagazig and died on the way presumably on account of his excess.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: (FROM OUR FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT)

London, August 4 After finishing up string last week, markets had a sharp check early in the present week, the reported ntterances of the Tsar and M. Witte being taken more seriously than was expected. Some are saying that the one real reason wy Russia might almost be said to fear peace is the internal state of the country and the possible consequences of recalling a beaten and dscontented army home, where her ttroubles are far from being at an end.

The truth ism that although investment business is really good there is little or no speculation on the part of the public and such speculative accounts as there are open are mostly all professional: Declare thought they had "seen their way" a little last week and opened small bull acounts, but with littl permanent effect, as the public declined to follwo suit Consols remain an uncertain market at 90 1/4 and Home Rails are generally weaker on the disappointing returns. In Foreign Bonds, War stocks are dull.

Egyptian stocks are steady and have shown a tendency tp harden lately. As we pointed out before, Agricultural Bank shares at the present price of 14 1/4, still carry the right to apply for the new shares ay 5. This brings the price of the old share down to 9 1/4 and the premium on the new shares is sucha very tempting one that the old shares is sucha very tempting one tha the old shares should still be well worth buying, and might easily rise to 16 or 17 between noe and the end of Septem- ber for they will not be quoted ex rights till about them as the application for the new must be lodged early in October.

In the Mining section the only point of interest is the new issue of 47,000 Nile Valley shares at 1 which ahs naturally brought the price of the old shares back to the same level, These 47,000 shares have been under option to Mr. J.B. Robinson at 30s per share and through efflution of time that option has now expired. The vigoroud development of the mine at depth and an extension of the crush- ing capacity are the main reasons advanced for the issue but as the issue price is par and the old shares owing to the fall to-day, may be had in the market for 18s 9d. there would appear to be little in it. Apart from a small decline in "Mummies" other Egyptian Mines were not mentioned.

div.head: MARKETING AT THE DOOR.
div.p: To be sure it was a great enterprise for us to take a cottage in a French fishing village we having little French and to import an English cook, who had no French at all. Our French speaking friends raised their hands at our daring. "You will be frightfully cheated" they assured us. "How on earth are you going to do your marketing? Why you don't even know the value of French money!"

THat was true of courswe. We had to begin by letting the vendors help themselves to their payments but that was for a day or two only. Our freinds underrated our intelligence but we found the decimal coinage esy of under standing and were only puzzled when some of the more unsophisticated skipped from centimes to sous with a startling rapidity.

Even here there is a season which begina about the last week in July. We arrived in the third week and were pertubed to find that a week later prices suddenly jumped up. That was because the big hotel was filling with English. Apparently the French visitors have no influence on the season for the cha;ets were full of French people when we came; but of course Madame knows the full value of what she buys and it would be quite useless to name an extortinate price with her. Indeedm we noticed at first that when Madame came to purchase at the carts at the same time as we were purchasing prices were mentioned in a whisper. However, that was before we learned to do without rather than to pay overmuch. When we had to come to that point we began to be treated with respect. But before we arrived there Zelie the fishwoman had made a tre- mendous haul out of us. We had paid her five francs for six small fish the result of stupefac- tion rather than of anyting else. Since then we have ceased to deal with Zelie

Fish there is an abundance and fresh out of the sea, very often "All alive, O!" We generally dismiss two or thee fishsellers before breakfast. The earyly hours are a disadvantage. WE are on the ground-floor, and the hall door with is screen of pierced ironwork, is at our bed head. It is disquieting when a cry of "Des moules, inadame sil vous plait" pierces one's ear at six o'clock in the morning. You may buy seven basinful of mussels for three pence as our cook did yesterday but even so early an hour.

After bathing you may buy eels on the sands and carry them home, writhing in whatever happens to be hanady. Also, as you sit at meals it is no uncommon thing to have a crab or a lobster thrust through the open window each quite ready to show fight. After we have bought them they promenade round the kitchen to the amusement od our cook, whom we sus0 pect of a French-descent. We also buy a flat, thick, white fish, which is very sweet and delicate of a variety unknown to us, Then there is a glittering silverfish very like a salmon, which they cal "bar" and for which they charge salmon prices. It eats rather like a milder kind of salmon. Can it be barbel?

Mademoiselle who sells us our fruit and vegetables comes out from Boulogue market. She has a little ass and cart and a'stout dog to assist "l'auesse" up the hilld and down, She has beautiful peaches and melons and plums and tomatoes and all manner of vegetables. As she sits on her cart, with her handsome dark face she is the centre of a most pleasing pictue. We like her the better that is well fed and accustomed to sugar and that the dog turns up his nose at mere bread. Still, she has picked over the peaches fo us, giving us the least mature while the French. medames selected the ripest and roundest. How impossible it is to remonstrate when one has little French! Then there comes a day when she can speak only in a whisper and has her throat swathed up with bandages. We present her with some tabloids of chlorate of potash. The next time she comes she thanks and we notice that she lays aside our selection of a caterpillar-ridden lettuce for a better one. At Tuesday's market she takes charge of us. We see her watching over us from afar. Not any longer does she pick for us the hardest and greenest peaches.

There is a delightful little olf woman who comes from Cape GRisnez with adonkey cart full of butter and eggs. The butter, swathed in cabbage leaves under a white cloth is de- licious past the "best Devon" of London shops. The eggs are brown and new-laid. Sometimes a child comes to the dooe with three or four warm eggs on a platter, asking a few sous.-

Again, there re those who appear at the door wiht a shrieking and miserable pullet or duck wiht its legs tied together. Or the baker like a conjurerm will produc a rabbit from amid his long brownloaves. Or again there is the woman with her little brown face in its widefrilled white cap a brown as her wares.

Once there is a misunderstanding. The boy of the knife-grinder has been hanging enrap- tured over the oyster-man as he opens the oysters for his customers. Presently the bpy appears in our open door. "French" we say in our halting French. "French" re plies. "Very cheap" we say to each other approvingly and straight way oder two dozen. "E have not go" them", he syas shaking his bewildered head WE produce a long dish and thrust it under his nose. His bewilderment but increases Pantomime fails. He leaves us at last still shaking his head. Those mad Enlgish I L to himself, doubtless. It is only when we see him trudging by the knife-grinder's cart that we realise our mistake.
We have favorites among those itinerant merchants those whom it is hard to turn away, so that we sometimes rather load our- selves up with eggs and butee because
we cannot say "No" to the little mahogany faced old women.

Occasionally we get other things than pro- visons: Yesterday it was a couple of plausible fellow, gispy-faced children of the sun with a long cary full of chairs, the new varnish alll gleaming in the sun. They leap on the chiars toprove that they are "tres solide" and an excellent test it is, for they are great and brawny even by those sons of Anak our fishermen.

Or it is a tied-up bundle of silk bedspreads and embroidered tanle-centres, costly and beautiful. We have to see to the bottom of the bundle, although we know full well that we shall not buy. Madame seems to find it a pleasure to make the display. When at last we convey our apologies she answerd cheerfully that it is all in the way of business. "Merci bien madame" she says going out. Certainly they sweeten life; those excellent manners of our French neighbours. KATHERINE TYNAN.

div.head: THE JUNGFRAU RAILWAY
div.p: A further step has been made towards the completion of the railway which is to transport tourists to the summit of the Jungfrau. A year ago the station of Eigerwant which is about 9,000 feet above the sea level was opened and it wsa announced that the next station Eismeer, 950 feet higher up, would in all probability be readyby August 1. How well the engineers made their calcula- tions can be gauged from the fact that trains went through the Kismeer on the 27th ult.- that is to say, a wwek before the appointed date; an d this notwithstanding that a tunnel nearly a mile in length had to be bored through the hard stone and rock of the Eiger.

There was great excitement at Interlaken when it was known tha the line was open and crowds thronged outto Lauterbrunnen and Wengernlap in order to take advantage of the new extension. Special trians had to be put on and the pressure continued until the evening. It was at first feard that the opening would have to be postponed owing to the inclement weather which prevailed on the previos days but yesterday was an ideal summer day and so the opening took place.

The view from Eigerwand is nearly always sploit by a mist which constantly comes and goes but up at Eismeer the atmosphere was perfectly clear anf the view of the Alps was superb. Indeed, Eismeer is always free from mist and fog and so one can almost always rely on a clear view. This latter station is hewn out of the solid rock which lies midway at the foot of the summits of the Eiger and the Monch. From the Eismeer the tip of the Fiescherhoner can be seen, as also the Schreckhorn and Wetterhorn and down below before one's eyes stretches the Eiger glacier with terrible abysses and gigantic gorges. It is a sight which excites intense admiration and at the same time causes the spectator un- willingly to shudder.

By next summer it is hoped to have a road open up to the sumts of the Eiger and the Monch whilst the railway will be continued along the Col de Jungfran to the point from which a gigantic life will convey passengers up a tunnel bored through the mountain to the summit. This last section will be the most difficult and when it is completed it will be the crowning example of what modern engineer- ing genius can achieve.

div.head: A PROTECTION AGAINST MOSQUITOES
div.p: Mr. Walter J. Hammond writed form the City ofLondon Club Old Broad-street E.C IN 1890 fever broke out in the town of Rio Claro S. BAulo Brazil where I was staying obliging me to remove to San Carlos. In my new residence there were no mosquito nets for the beds so for two nights I has no refreshing sleep on account of mosquitos. All who have experienced similar misery know how weary and desperate we become through the constant onslaught of the insects which prevent sound sleep however weary and tired the body may be. Knowning kerosine oill or petroleum to be destructive of all insect life. I annointed my face, neck, and hands witht he oil and so got some sleep; but as soon as it had evaporated teh creaturs were at me again. My eye fell on the washstand and in a happy moment I thought of mixinf the petroleum oil in a string lather of soap. The effect was perfect and I slept until the morning in peace. Until I had mosqioto nets arranged I used this moxture every nights with th esame happy result. Numbers of my friends have used this preventive not only for the terrible mosquito that conveys the germs of yellow fever or other awful diseases but to keep off gnats of all kinds midges which are to be found in England. I write this because so many persons have at times to sleep a night or two in mosquito-infected towns where nets are not always available. The proportion I found best was about a small coffee spoonful of petroluem to a latehr of soap and water which when free from bubbles would fill one-third of the soap dish. The mixture of course smells sightly of the oil but it is not any stringer than old brown Windsor or coal-tar soaps. No injury whatever is done to the skin, however often it is need and the slight discomfort felt at first is compensated a thousandfold by the mmunity it establishes from mosquito or gnat results and the attendant dangers.

div.head: MAT HAFFIGAN;S ADVOCATE
div.p: When Mr. George Bernard Shaw wrote "John Bull's Other Island" he invented Mr. Mathew Haffigan as a type of the land- hungering Irishman whose "sufferings" had almost turned his head and to whome nothing was of the least service that did not begin and end with the restoration to "the people" of the land to which he supposed them to have an indefeasible right. A violent and not very brilliant old person, he was quite unable to understand that when the "land" had passed in small holdings into the hands of men who lacked means as much as the old landloards and lacked also the education and influence which enabled their predecessors in many instances to do their duty by their tentants Ireland would be in worse case than ever before. His socialism was of that unreasoning kind that can olny see the attractive begining and is deluded by a belief that a inevitable end, in which all the old evils have new evils added unto them can be indefinately postponed, MR. Shaw who knows his own island, invented this Haffigan to show his folly, But Mr. Shawm though a Fabian is a shrewd studnet of national life

Count Tolstoy who devotes seven long if interesting columns of the "Times" to an ex- posiition of his well-known views on the re- generation of Russia is a Socialist and a dreamer. So he follows Haffigan rather than Shaw. TO demonstrate his views on the land question for Russia (which he compares in one passage to Ireland), he had invented many characters (whom he introduces in a narrative passage) whose "sufferings" and aspirations are not unlike our friend Matthew's . But form these premisses he goes on to argue tha the nationalisation of land is absolutley the only panaces for the ills to which his country if heir and that all reform or attempted re- form which does not start from this point is a hindrance and not a help.

Count Tolstoy is both violent and visionary. His dreams are haunted by the figure of Henry George whose doctirine of which the manifest fallacies were long ago acknowldged is quoted and accepted by him as the indestructible argu- ment of an inspired reformer. Having got the one idea of the land question and its solution firmly fixed in his mind as the only true hope of or road to national salvation there is room for nothing else.And he devotes a vast amount of zealous energy to a bitter denuciation of all reformers who are seeking in other direc- tions the regenration of Russia. Private owner- ship of land is an "atrocity." All who disagree with Leo Tolstoy are sinful Scribes and Pha- rises "like unto whited sepulchres" and "only those who are not religous and there- fore do not truly love can invent trifling unimportant improvements in the condition of the people wihtout seeing that cheif evil from which others are suffering and which they themselves are partly producing" land-hunger to wit. Such "unimportant improvements" are efforts "to abolish the censorship of books, arbitrary banishments and to organise every- where schoold, common and agricultural, to increase the numebr of hospitals, to cancle passports and monoplies to institute strict inspection in the factories to reward maimed workers, to mark boundaries between pro- pertis of land by peasants and much else." And all who devote themselves to merely practical ideals such as these, Liberal, Social- ists, Revolutionists, or Governemt officials are preverse, blind and sinful. In fact, aut Tolstoy aut nullus and ot hte crows with all reforms and reformers who do not belive that the nationalisation of land is the one and ony hope for Russia.

This singular outburst interesting and amaz- ing shows clearly enough why the idealistic noble is permitted a latitude which the Russian Government does not often allow to thinkers so free and courageous. The more Count Tolstoy writes in this fashion the more he sows dissen sion in the party reform. His words directly and the GOvernment by separating peasants from "intellectuals" and causing a great disrtrust of those who might lead were the country as a whole to follow. Supposing that his ideal were less impractible than is actually the case, he still puts the cart before the horse and retards any possible realisation of hisown desires by decrying to reform of Governemnt which must be ther first step on a new path for his country. How so keen an intellect can believe or write as he does is something of a mystery but it is clear enough that he must do a great deal of harm to the cause of intelligent reform, while the bureaucracy mus t find in his activity a valued ally in their war aganst the "intellectuals" whom they have reson to dread. MR. G.B. Shaw made another of his puppets call Mat Haffigan a "foostering old dodderer" Count Leo Tolstoy would have bailed him as a true disciple. But while there is hope in Ireland, there can be little for Russia where doctors continue so disastorously to disagree.

div.head: COMPLET DES COURSES
div.p: "PAAAris sport Complet des courses! Reeeesultat complet des courses! PAAris sport complet!" Streaming with perspiration wild eyed, red-faced hoarse yoiced and "debrailles" no Elnglish word conveys such an exact description of the utter abandonment of their dishevelled state- the "camelots" who are selling, eveing papers with the result of to-day's racing at MAisons-Laffitte tear past the office windowm pattering down the hot boulevard upon their string-soled espadrilles- shoes of white drill with laces of bright blue.

"PAAAris sport! Complet des courses!" I have wondered sometimes whether thesemen be millionaires dyspeptic men in search of violent exercise who in spite of their rags, ahve ple- thora of moeny at the bank. Their cheif design seems to be speed and they do not appear to want to sell their ares. If they do sell them they do so as the rish by and nothing short of the police can stop them Why, I have seen them thrust a paper into a man's hand ansd go on wihtout the halfpenny becuase he could not get the coin out quickly enogh for the camelot's taste.

"PAAAris sport!" On they rush a quire or two of the damp papers in onr hand, the other free to take your halfpenny and thrust the paper into your hand. This sometimes only. FOr although there must be fifty hawkers selling the same paper within 500 yeards each man runs as though his life depended on his gettting farther up the street, or farther down it as the case may be and tears along in desperate earnestness of haste, missing five customers for every one to whome he sells a paper.

"PAAri sport! Complet des courses!" "Sac a papier!" grumbles an old concierge in velet skullcap (it is Sunday) and huge horn-rimmed spectacles- "Sac a papier! I knew that Sabre- tache was bound to win! And" turning to his wife sitting hand on her knees on a small stool beside the doorway "you and your Verdigris! You would not let me play Sabre- tache, and you see the result! Ninety-eight francs for five!" "I dreamed that there was Verdigris upon the firt floor's copper sauce0 pans," meekly says Madame Concierge The tip seemed good enough you know last year...." "Last year, last year! I should have won ninety-eight francs in Sabretache instead of losinf five on your absurd Verdigris, growls the lord of creation. "Last year! Les voila bien les femmes!"

"PAAris sport! Compley des courses!: A little owrk-girl in her Sundat best looks down the paper feverishly then claps her hands re- gaurdless of the new gloves on them and ex- claims "Forty0nine franc! Yes hald of ninety-eight of forty-nine and Jeanne and I have ninety-eight frnacs to divde! Quelle veine! quelle veine!" She picks the paper from the pavement where she had dropped it in her excitement and glances down the other races. "Vasistas-not even placed! Five fracs gone, for Jeanna would not bet on him. Well never mind; I've made my forty some- thing francs anyhow!"

"PAAris sport!" A methodical old gentle- man the least liekly man in Paris to have betted you would think buys the paper sits down at the cafe order a grenadine which he forgets to drink and wiht a pencil a notebook and the newly bought paper works out the results of the day. Six of the seven horses he had backed have places. The seventh one has lost. A net gain of eighteen franc fifty "PAAris sport!" A man as ragged as the camelot gives him his last sopper and breaks into loud curses. "PAris sport!"

It's eight o'clock. The hawker alost dead with heat and weariness drops on a seat upon the Boulevard St. Danis. He is voiceless his heart thumps underneath his tattered shirt the open neck of which shows the veind of his throat tight-strung like the catgut of a violin. But he has sold all his paers and has made his wahe of two francs. Enough to live on for another day, and more by a good deal than the day's "sport" has brought to may of his pockets, curls up on the bench and goes to sleep. "Paris sport" He jumps up and shakes himself. Time to get up and sell the "Courrier de Soir."

div.head: YACHTING PROSPECTS AT COWES
div.p: Not fo many years observes the "Yachts- man" has the outlook for Cowes been brighter. One factor alone remains- an all important one and should the weather not be propitions our hopes may be blasted. THe coincidence of the visit of the French fleet will make a bright mark at done which the Press would make a bright mark for that mysterious midnight meeting of the royal yachts of Russia and Germanu which has taken place in the Baltic. These are shoal waters into which we cannot ventue; fortu- nately, we are not dependent on outsiders for our Cowes. As a matter of factm however, the Metero will be present and it is highly impro- bable that the gay week on the Solent will ruffle the political sea. Not for many years has there been so much demand for accommodtion on shore or for anchorage a fleat. Britannia will holat her o'd colours and the racing should be exceptionally good.
